metadata.title: Staccato Tamping: Improving Espresso without a Sifter | by Robert McKeon Aloe | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Staccato Tamping: Improving Espresso without a Sifter
metadata.description: Most of my coffee experiments are done casually throughout the day. Because of the shelter in place orders, I moved my coffee bar to my house, and I’ve had a fair amount of lattes and non-staccato…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: another person ran across something similar
Coffee Solubility in Espresso: An Initial Study
Espresso Simulation: First Steps in Computer Models
The Tale of the Stolen Espresso Machine

all_paragraphs: Most of my coffee experiments are done casually throughout the day. Because of the shelter in place orders, I moved my coffee bar to my house, and I’ve had a fair amount of lattes and non-staccato espresso shots. Regular espresso shots are mainly desirable to me for the time aspect (much quicker than staccato shots) which jives well with espresso drinks. Half my shots at home have been regular shots, and I stumbled across staccato tamping out of convenience.

The technique is not new, but how it functions has been unknown until now. Simply put, staccato tamping is filling the basket halfway, tamping, filling the rest, and tamping again. The difference between previous work and this work is the understanding of why it makes a better shot and the special trick in the two tamps derived from the theory. Staccato tamping is not split tamping (dose half, tamp X lbs, dose second half, tamp X lbs where X is defined by the barista). Staccato tamping is dose half, tamp X lbs, dose second half, tamp Y lbs where Y is much less than X.

In this article, I describe the previous work, the staccato tamping theory and methodology, and some numerical results where I explore for a better understanding of how the method functions. The beauty is that anyone with an espresso machine can attempt this technique at home as long as they have a tamper and a steady hand.

A forum in 2003 had a short discussion on the split tamp technique, where there was much skepticism except for one or two who used something similar. They called it double tamp or double dose or split tamp.
In 2005, someone started a discussion on tamping at the halfway mark. They didn’t know why it made an improvement, but they noticed something.
In 2009, a barista was seen tamping the first half and then the second half with a 30 lbs tamp. They had been doing this for some time.
In 2015, there was a short discussion on Reddit about double tamping but no explanation or claim that it was better.

In 2017, another person ran across something similar, but like the previous threads, there wasn’t a theory on how this technique functioned. They asked if there was a name. Potentially, double tamp would be a good name, but based on how it improves the shot, staccato tamping is more applicable.
All of these examples are clear in that they don’t do a range of experiments to examine coffee extraction nor does anyone really understand what physically would allow a split tamp to succeed.

I have been using roasted beans from Hawai’i, and they were a dark medium roast. As a result, they take up more volume when ground, and I wasn’t used to using only 18g in my 20g basket when I typically use 22g. It could get messy, so I started split tamping (dose, tamp, dose, leveler).

Around the same time, I had been working on doing visual analysis for why I kept seeing donut extractions even with Staccato espresso shots. They don’t have the same kind of channeling issues because each layer has a more even particle distribution.

My typical staccato shot is 8g fine (<400um) on the bottom, 8g coarse (>500um), 6g mid (between 400um and 500um) on top. From simulations, channelling is always occurring in a normal distribution of particles, but by splitting layers, the channeling affect is reduced causing better extraction.

In my donut analysis, I thought the donut shape was caused by the fine layer, but I discovered the mid layer on top of the puck had the biggest impact. If all the fine particles aren’t sifted out or the tamp is too hard, I get a lot of channeling. The theory was that channeling doesn’t exist much in the coarse particles as they can’t be compressed much through tamping. The fine particles can be compressed, but when the water hits them, they fuse together causing it to behave differently. The evidence to support this theory is that the fine layer is on the bottom but doesn’t clog the filter holes as one would think. The mid layer, however, can be compressed more than the coarse and appears to be highly sensitive.

To better understand this variable, I started tracking in my data sheet how far down the leveler was going instead of using something like the force applied to the tamper. I found the lightest pressure worked the best, and dialing in a grinder turned into literally dialing my leveler up or down.

Staccato tamping was the result of applying knowledge from the staccato shot to a regular shot. The layering in a staccato shot is ultimately layers of coffee densities as a result of the particle sizes. So, if you have two layers of different coffee densities, the result could be modified to come out similar to a staccato espresso shot. In staccato tamping, the bottom layer had a higher density than the top which simulates sifting the grounds and having a shot with a fine layer on bottom.

This setup was derived from some experimentation where I was mainly focused on getting a good extraction and a high Total Dissolved Solids (TDS). I was using these test shots in espresso drinks, not straight shots. Then I tried a few espresso shots using this tamping technique, and the results were definitely better.
I use two metrics for evaluating the differences between techniques: Final Score and Coffee Extraction.

Final score is the average of a scorecard of 7 metrics (Sharp, Rich, Syrup, Sweet, Sour, Bitter, and Aftertaste). These scores were subjective, of course, but they were calibrated to my tastes and helped me improve my shots. There is some variation in the scores. My aim was to be consistent for each metric, but some times the granularity was difficult.

Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) is measured using a refractometer, and this number combined with the output weight of the shot and the input weight of the coffee is used to determine the percentage of coffee extracted into the cup.

For data collection, I wanted a small data collection experimenting with how much grounds should go for the first tamp vs the second. In the case when all the grounds go in the first tamp, I used the lever at the same position as I did for other variants. The result is that the bottom layer is denser than the top layer. I looked at this for two cases: a regular shot and one with a paper filter in the filter (PFF) which has a damp Aeropress filter at the bottom.

I also fully acknowledge that I don’t have a statistically significant dataset. I had some issues controlling output due to using a lever machine which can’t fit a scale underneath. Additionally, unlike other studies I’ve done, I’m more interested in pulling regular staccato espresso shots, so I didn’t want to spend a large chunk of time getting a paired set of regular shots and staccato tamped shots. These results show a jump in performance for taste and extraction, particularly when using a paper filter on the bottom.

I also inspected a few of these visually to understand how the shot looked underneath. The left side is the 18/0 shot which is a normal tamping using a leveler as a tamper. The right shot is the 9/9 staccato tamped shot. The third frame shows the coffee filling the bottom of the filter faster than the regular shot indicating better flow.

What about Paper Filter in the Filter (PFF) techniques? Could they be modified in a similar way like in Staccato shots? I previously found the best place for a PFF in staccato shots was between the fine and coarse layers. For staccato tamped shots, I tried the bottom and the middle. I found the PFF in between the two layers to be more beneficial. This suggests that PFF’s aren’t reducing clogging of the filter but are reducing channeling through the puck.

Here is a comparison of another roast for Staccato Tamped vs Staccato Espresso. Staccato Espresso was still better, but Staccato Tamped was pretty good. It’s definitely a nice medium between the work required for a Staccato Espresso shot and the taste improvement.

Why does a staccato tamped shot seem to perform better? I believe it acts like a staccato espresso shot, so the less dense layer on top fully saturates with little channeling. Then the bottom layer doesn’t have much room to channel in significant ways. This points to the top of the puck being so important because channeling at the top only snowballs as the water gets to the bottom. While the bottom layer is denser, the water is coming through that layer more evenly.

I dried a few pucks to help see where the extraction was occurring. For PFF in the middle, it seems the majority of the extraction is in the top layer which can also be seen with spent pucks. Staccato shots have more extracted from the fine layer, so there is still some fundamental difference between the two because sifter coffee layers have less variance so less channeling.

In this article, I have shown preliminary evidence that staccato tamping provides a better taste than regular tamping, and I have proposed a theory as to why a split tamping technique could improve espresso. I’ve also shown some initial results suggesting a paper filter in the middle of the shot would be better than on the bottom.
The best part is that anyone already making espresso can try this at home!
If you like, follow me on Twitter and YouTube where I post videos of espresso shots on different machines and espresso related stuff. You can also find me on LinkedIn.
